DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

China and the US have basically reached a broad consensus on a phase one trade deal including the removal of tariffs, according to China's Global Times citing experts close to the talks, although reports added some differences remain over how much tariffs should be rolled back. (Newswires)

China's Foreign Ministry commented regarding the US designation of Huawei and ZTE as national security threats, in which it urged the US to stop its abuse of the concept of national security and Chinese companies. (Newswires)

China is preparing to focus its attention to strengthening ties with Europe next year amid US trade talks and following the signing of the "geographical indication" agreement to protect for 100 regionally specific products, according to sources. (SCMP)

PBoC said downward pressure on the Chinese economy is increasing and potential risks and problems are difficult to eliminate in the short-term, while it added that China will implement greater tax cuts and will increase local govts special bond quota. (Newswires)

Taiwan Government is to purchase more US goods to avoid being named a currency manipulator, which includes military equipment, oil, gas and agri products, according to sources. (Newswires)

China reportedly summoned the US ambassador over Hong Kong interference. (Newswires)

 

UK/EU

ICM/Reuters Poll on UK Election showed Conservatives 41% (-1 point), Labour 34% (+2 points). (Newswires) 

YouGov are to release their MRP model poll at 22:00GMT on Wednesday via The Times. Note: In the run up to the 2017 general election, YouGov's MRP model successfully predicted the hung parliament as such the model is the main one to watch in the lead up to this election. (Newswires)

ECB's Lane said the yield curve plays a key role for the transmission of monetary policy, under both standard and non-standard policy measures, while Lane added the ECB will be in the bond market for a long time and is signalling quantitative tightening but far in the future. (Newswires)

ECB's Holzmann stated that monetary policy objectives will be available for discussion in upcoming months. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

Iranian-backed Houthis reportedly launched a large-scale attack against Saudi-led coalition forces in Yemen which is said to have left hundreds of casualties including Saudi, Emirati and Sudanese nationals. (MasirahTV/Elinor News)

 

US

US President Trump said the USMCA trade agreement is on House Speaker Pelosi's desk and suggested she is incapable of moving it, while he added that Mexico and Canada might pull the deal pretty soon and that if they do pull it, it is her fault and not his. (CNBC)

 

MARKET RECAP

Tesla (TSLA) pared back some recent losses after CEO Musk tweeted impressive order figures for its Cybertruck. Uber Inc (UBER) took a hit following London removing its license to operate. Nvidia (NVDA) led semiconductors amid an upgrade at Morgan Stanley on anticipation of stronger gaming revenue in 2020. Netflix (NFLX) opened on the backfoot post a downgrade to Underperform at Morgan Stanley, but reversed course through the session as major bourses pushed to new ATHs. CVS Health (CVS) saw a late session bounce on a WSJ report stating Starboard value has taken a stake and the two have held amicable talks. S&P 500 0.8% at 3134, NASDAQ-100 1.2% at 8372, Dow Jones 0.7% at 28067.

T-notes edged higher on Monday despite a strong US equity market performance putting constraint on the bid for havens. Participants also could be cautious on US debt markets given the large Treasury supply this week, although month-end rebalancing out of equities and into Treasuries is also likely providing support. The shape of the curve was little changed at settlement with yields lower between one and two basis points. US T-note futures (Z9) settled 2 ticks higher at 1929-16+.

subject: RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 25th November 2019: China to ramp up IP penalties in a seemingly good-will gesture
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equities up, Treasuries flat/up, dollar flat, crude up,
  • REAR VIEW: China to intensify IP theft punishments, Phase One agreement is near, MC FP offer USD 135 for TIF, SCHW officially announced take-over proposal of AMTD, eBay to sell StubHub for USD 4bln
  • NEXT WEEK: Data: German GfK Consumer Sentiment; US Consumer Confidence, New Home Sales-Units, API Weekly Inventories. Events: Fed Discount Rate Minutes. Speakers: Fed’s Powell, Brainard; ECB’s de Guindos, Coeure, Lane; RBA Governor Lowe. Supply: UK.

 

* MARKET WRAP: Equity bourses found the strength to make new highs to start the week following some, at face value, positive developments on the US-China trade front: China said over the weekend it would ramp up its intellectual property theft penalties, a seemingly goodwill gesture from Beijing to secure the Phase One tariff rollback agreement; China Global Times posted another report on Monday to squash negative reports/commentary, suggesting China was committed to reaching a deal and committed to the next phases of a deal. Treasuries were little changed ahead of large issuance this week - the 2-year auction was decent on Monday - in addition to month-end rebalancing flows into the complex. The crude benchmarks edged higher, benefitting from the China-trade induced risk appetite, which meanwhile saw havens XAU and JPY fare worse. Elsewhere in FX, cable was an outperformer following weekend polls indicating a further lead for incumbent PM Johnson. The risk appetite saw the cyclical tech sector lead the pack, boosted by the semiconductors (SOX), with NVDA also surging on an upgrade at Morgan Stanley. "Merger Monday" was very much in play, with confirmation on the SCHW-AMTD, TIF-LVMH and MDCO-NOV deals, in addition to EBAY selling its StubHub unit. The NY Fed carried out its first term repo through year-end on Monday, which was oversubscribed as primary dealers seized the opportunity to lock in low rate financing ahead of expected year-end funding pressures. Participants now look to Fed Chair Powell's speech later on Monday evening, in addition to earnings from A, HPE, PANW.

* US/CHINA: Over the weekend, China said it would seek to raise penalties for IP violations and lower the thresholds for criminal punishments as a result of technology theft -- seemingly a concession in trade talks with the US -- according to a State Council and Communist Party’s Central Office opinion document. The opinion states that progress should be seen by 2022, and by 2025 a better system for protection will be in place. Intellectual property rights and enforcement has been a key US demand in trade talks but is not expected to be part of the phase one trade deal. However, with US/China negotiators reportedly to meet this week, it may lower the bar for a conclusion of the phase one deal, which could see a partial rollback of tariffs and a postponement/cancelling of further tariffs due to come into effect on 15th December. Although the news was being framed by analysts as a concession in trade talks with the US, other reports note China said talks on a 'phase 2' deal would take place only after the US Presidential elections in November 2020, essentially pushing any real negotiating into 2021, some analysts said. However, the China Global Times -- often seen as a mouthpiece for the China state -- reported that contrary to negative media reports, China and the US were very close to the phase one agreement, and China remains committed to continuing talks for a phase two or even a phase three deal with the US, citing experts close to the Chinese government. 

* FED'S POWELL: Set to speak at 0000 GMT/1900 ET, Fed Chair Powell is likely stick to the script and repeat recent remarks that the Fed policy stance "likely to remain appropriate" as long as incoming data was consistent with the Fed's outlook, and if developments cause a material re-assessment in the Fed's outlook, it will respond accordingly. Powell will likely retain his upbeat on the US economy, seeing a favourable baseline where a sustained expansion of activity, strong labour markets and inflation is near its symmetric 2.0% goal. The Fed chair will likely allude to noteworthy risks given sluggish global growth and trade developments still pose risks, while he may again also warn on persistent below-target inflation weighing on longer-term inflation expectations.

* TERM REPO: The NY Fed conducted its first term repo operation extending into the new year on Monday. Primary dealers (PDs) were keen to take up the offer with the USD 25bln offered receiving USD 49bln in bids, a significant oversubscription for the 42-day agreement; meanwhile, the overnight operations remained undersubscribed on Monday. With year-end repo rates priced at just shy of 3.5% (according to ICAP data), PDs were keen to take advantage of the current 1.6% rate for funding through the period. Ahead of Monday’s operations, Deutsche Bank’s analysts noted that it would be a warning sign if the term operation were undersubscribed, as it could indicate the Fed’s operations are ineffective at aiding the distribution of liquidity across the financial system around year-end, citing G-SIB banks perhaps being incentivised to avoid repo trades to avoid rising into higher G-SIB buckets or European banks wanting to avoid higher capital charges from a higher leverage ratio. Ad-hoc analysis suggests these fears are yet to materialise given the oversubscription, but participants now look towards next Monday for the next term repo operation through year-end. Additionally, with the Thanksgiving holiday at the tail-end of this week, month-end flows and Treasury settlement - not to mention the Treasury issuance this week - the overnight and short-term repo markets could face some pressures.

* US BUDGET: House and Senate negotiators late Friday reached a deal on top-line spending figures for the FY 2020 budget (a key sticking point that had prevented any final deal being reached), according to sources quoted by The Hill, following days of behind-the-scenes negotiations. Congress last week passed a stopgap spending bill this week, giving lawmakers until 20th December to prevent a shutdown, and in order to achieve that, it will need to pass either an agreement, or another continuing resolution. The Hill speculates that lawmakers have around 15 session dates to iron out details and pass the bill in both the House and the Senate.

* US ELECTIONS: Former NY mayor Michael Bloomberg announced on the weekend he will enter the Presidential race, seeking the Democrat nomination. Bloomberg enters the race late, just three months before the first of the state-by-state party nominating contests, and reportedly reflects his scepticism that any of the other Democratic candidates can unseat US President Trump. Bloomberg News said on Sunday it will not investigate its Michael Bloomberg, continuing its policy of limiting coverage of its top executive, though would still do initiative and investigative reporting on US President Trump, though has said it would revisit its policy on Michael Bloomberg if he wins the primaries.

* HONG KONG: Pro-democracy groups made large gains in district council elections, with 17 of the 18 councils are now controlled by pro-democracy councillors. Voting went ahead peacefully, despite fears it might have been cancelled due to unrest. Some had viewed the election as a test of support for the government after months of unrest, BBC reported, the government and Beijing had been hoping the election would show support from the so-called "silent majority", but that did not materialise; on the contrary, pro-Beijing candidates lost council seats. Meanwhile, as US President Trump is yet to announce action on whether he will sign the Hong Kong Bill that was recently passed by Congress -- which would require periodic reviews of HK's special trading status -- China ratchet-up criticism of the US, accusing it of meddling in China's domestic affairs.

* UK ELECTION: Weekend polling (with the survey period covering the end of last week) showed Conservatives leading Labour by between 10-19% (from around 10-18% versus the previous weekend, though the 19ppts lead reported by Opinium is the largest lead since campaigning began). Much of the Tories gains were at the expense of the Brexit Party, while there have been some positive moves in the support for the LibDems. An analysis in the Sunday Times suggested that if polls stay at current levels, it would imply a majority of around 50 seats for the Conservatives.

* ECB: ECB's Lane stated the ECB will be in the bond market for a long time, adding ECB is signalling quantitative tightening but far in the future. When asked what the ECB would do if the inflation outlook worsens, says the best guide could be what the ECB did in September, namely, a little bit of everything. Lane also spoke yields, noting the recent rise in yields suggests that investors are a little less pessimistic about the economy, noting the yield curve plays a key role for the transmission of monetary policy, under both standard and non-standard policy measures.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (Z9) SETTLES 2 TICKS HIGHER AT 1929-16+. The T-note edged higher on Monday with a strong US equity market performance putting constraint on the bid for havens. Participants also could be cautious on US debt markets given the large Treasury supply this week, although month-end rebalancing out of equities and into Treasuries is also likely providing support. The shape of the curve was little changed at settlement with yields lower between one and two basis points.

* 2-YEAR REVIEW: The US sold USD 40bln in 2-year notes at 1.601%, stopping through the WI by 0.4bps and covered at the average ratio in what was a decent auction. Directs took approximately 29%, well above the average, whilst indirects took just under their average and dealers took a haircut on their average.

* THIS WEEK'S SUPPLY: The Treasury will this week sell a new 2-year note (USD 40bln, Monday), a new 5-year note (USD 41bln, Tuesday), and a new 7-year note (USD 32bln, Wednesday). Analysts at UBS say that the Treasury will give some USD 92bln in cash redemptions and coupon payments this week, implying net cash flows of around 21bln.

* 5-YEAR AUCTION PREVIEW: Last month's auction saw decent demand from investment funds. The current 5s note appears to be trading fair in asset swap vs older 5s, SocGen says, while it appears to be slightly cheap on the curve against 2s and 10s. SocGen argues that the auction appears to be cheap on an outright basis, given that the current WI is trading above all stop out rates of the last three auctions. Additionally, the bank says that relatively low dealer holdings in the 3 to 6-year bucket should also support demand at the auction. The bank holds a positive bias into the sale.

* WTI (F0) SETTLES USD 0.24 HIGHER AT USD 58.01/BBL; BRENT (F0) SETTLES USD 0.26 HIGHER AT USD 63.35/BBL. Crude markets finished the day slightly higher, after a choppy session during which the complex largely failed to emulate the equity market’s strong performance. The complex derived some impetus after Marathon Petroleum’s (MPC) Los Angeles, California refinery (363k BPD) reported an unplanned breakdown and flaring but was unable to break out of the day’s range. It is also worth noting that a shortened week in the US means that month-end factors could also have been contributing to the choppiness. In separate crude-specific news; Iraq’s Southern oil fields, run by state-owned Basrah Oil, production has been operating at a 25% capacity for the majority of November as Baghdad works towards complying with its OPEC production limit, reported Argus. Finally, in separate supply related news, Libya’s El Sharara oil field is reportedly producing at a clip of close to its 310k BPD capacity.

* CLOSING LEVELS: S&P 500 0.8% at 3134, NASDAQ-100 1.2% at 8372, Dow Jones 0.7% at 28067

* SECTORS: Consumer Discretionary  0.9%, Consumer Staples  0.2%, Energy  0.2%, Financials  0.7%, Health Care  1.1%, Industrials  0.7%, Information Technology  1.4%, Materials  0.6%, Telecommunication Services  0.1%, Utilities  -0.4%

* M&A: Tiffany (TIF) surged after it reached an agreement for LVMH (MC FP) to acquire it for USD 135 in cash, or USD 16.2bln. TD Ameritrade (AMTD) also made strong gains after it confirmed it would be acquired by Charles Schwab (SCHW) for USD 26bln. Medicines Co (MDCO) made gains of over 20% after Novartis (NOVN SW, NOV) agreed to acquire it for USD 9.7bln, or USD 85/share. eBay (EBAY) opened higher, although did pare back, as it announced it would be selling its StubHub for USD 4.05bln to Viagogo. Kirkland Lake Gold (KL) traded lower after it agreed to buy out Detour Gold for just shy of CAD 5bln. Meanwhile, HP Inc (HPQ) has again rejected Xerox (XRX) after its latest acquisition offer.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Tesla (TSLA) pared back some recent losses after CEO Musk tweeted impressive order figures for its Cybertruck. Uber Inc (UBER) took a hit following London removing its license to operate. Nvidia (NVDA) led semiconductors amid an upgrade at Morgan Stanley on anticipation of stronger gaming revenue in 2020. Netflix (NFLX) opened on the backfoot post a downgrade to Underperform at Morgan Stanley, but reversed course through the session as major bourses pushed to new ATHs. CVS Health (CVS) saw a late session bounce on a WSJ report stating Starboard value has taken a stake and the two have held amicable talks.

* FX WRAP: USD traded relatively flat today with DXY trading in a a range of 98.17 at the lows to highs of 98.38. The buck managed to remain relatively stable despite yields falling slightly, appearing it to be propped up on haven outflows following positive US China trade rhetoric, which supported CNH. Early month end re-balancing may also be contributing to price action in the buck given the Thanksgiving holiday at the end of the week. Havens were generally weaker, particularly XAU and JPY, although CHF was rather flat. XAU traded in an 8-buck range with lows at 1454, where it resides heading into the overnight session. USDJPY was firmer on updates on US & China, where the cross found resistance spot on its 200dma at 108.97, a level which it floats within a whisker of heading into Asia-Pac trade. CHF flat against both EUR & USD. GBP a strong performer today following weekend polls where one poll had the market friendly conservatives hold a lead above labour as high as 19ppts. Cable initially crossed above the 1.29 handle, however fell back beneath the key level aided by a new ICM poll putting the Tory’s at just a seven-point lead. However, the move was short lived and the cross pared back to trade around the 1.29 handle towards the end of the session. EUR traded relatively rangebound against the greenback to start the week with lows at 1.10 and highs of 1.1032, the single currency failed to find impetus from this morning’s German IFO data which was in line with expectations, although Expectations slightly missed, but still picked up from the prior. The Antipodeans sold off once the US session went underway mainly as a function of a slightly stronger Dollar and now look set to end the US session modestly softer after its APAC impetus petered out. AUD/USD hovers just above session lows having tested 0.6800 to the upside overnight (vs. low 0.6769) whilst its Kiwi counterpart fell back below its 100 DMA at 0.6425 and looks to end the US session ~0.6400. EMFX was weaker across the board, with Lira falling after reports stated it begun testing the radar on the S-400 missile defence system. BRL also lower, Brazil’s FGV Consumer Confidence data fell from the prior print. MXN still weaker against the greenback, although less so than EM currencies following a strong economic activity data, although GDP Q/Q fell 0.1% short of expectations, although Y/Y was 0.1% stronger than the consensus. ZAR weaker amid comments from the IMF highlighting growth in the nation is to remain sluggish in 2021. The Rand also taking its cues from another poor credit rating, where S&P affirmed its rating, but revised its outlook to negative.

subject: PREVIEW: US to sell USD 40bln 2-year notes on Monday 25th November 2019, at 1800 GMT/1300 ET
content:
THIS WEEK'S SUPPLY: The Treasury will this week sell a new 2-year note (USD 40bln, Monday), a new 5-year note (USD 41bln, Tuesday), and a new 7-year note (USD 32bln, Wednesday). Analysts at UBS say that the Treasury will give some USD 92bln in cash redemptions and coupon payments this week, implying net cash flows of around 21bln. UBS also notes that it will be a big week for the short-end of the curve, with the first Fed repo operation over the turn as well as the Thanksgiving Holiday on Thursday, monthend on Friday, and the bank adds that we should expect a volatile week, with the landscape for the year-end turn to be clear once this week’s events are out of the way. For the 2-year auction, specifically, analysts at BMO say that the strength of the bid will likely continue to come from the domestic investor base, with m ore interest development being the extent of any concession heading into the truncated schedule.

subject: Daily FX Wrap: Stellar Sterling performance, Lira loses and DXY wobbles
content:
DXY, Yuan

The broad USD and Index initially staged a comeback as it rebounded off Asia-Pac lows - potentially influenced by early month-end rebalancing amid the holiday-shortened trading week. Overnight trade saw a softer Dollar after the Chinese government vaguely tightened its IP guidance, seemingly a concession. Trade developments remained quiet throughout the EU session, albeit a Global Times article did the rounds on US and China basically reaching broad consensus on Phase One, which employed very similar language to one posted over the weekend. DXY looks to end the EU session on a firmer footing and closer to the top of today’s 98.17-38 range having taken out its 50 DMA at 98.22 earlier in the session. Looking ahead, Fed Chair Powell scheduled to speak at midnight UK-time is unlikely to provide much by way of new substance given the high volume of Fed-speak in recent weeks. Meanwhile, USD/CNH remains heads into the end of the session modestly in the red and towards the middle of its intraday 7.0280-0420 band having tested resistance at its 21 WMA (7.0414) in overnight trade.

 

GBP, EUR

Sterling remains the top performer amongst G10 peers as it mimics gains seen last week from weekend polls showing a steady uptrend in the Conservative’s lead over the Labour party. Furthermore, analysis on YouGov data could be underpinning the currency as it projects the market-friendly Tory party with a parliamentary majority of 48. Meanwhile, the much-awaited YouGov MRP model is set to be released at 2200GMT on Wednesday, which successfully predicted a hung parliament in the run up to the 2017 general election. Cable topped its 21 DMA at 1.2879 to a high just north of 1.2900 before stabilising around the round figure. Meanwhile, EUR/USD was little impacted by the Ifo Survey which printed a modest improvement in the three metrics but was caveated by cautious comments from the institute, who noted that it is too early to speak of a German economic turnaround. EUR/USD heads into the EU close just north of 1.1000 having traded within a daily band of 1.1005-30 with touted support around 1.0990-94 should the round figure be breached.

 

AUD, NZD, JPY

The Antipodeans have reversed earlier gains but mainly as a function of the stronger Dollar and now look set to end the European day modestly softer after its APAC impetus petered out. AUD/USD hovers just above session lows having tested 0.6800 to the upside overnight (vs. low 0.6772) whilst its Kiwi counterpart fell back below its 100 DMA at 0.6425 and looks to end the EU session ~0.6400. Elsewhere, safe-haven outflow coupled with a firmer USD sees USD/JPY inching closer to the 109.00 mark having topped its 21 DMA at 108.76 and clocking in a 30-pip intraday range heading into the EU close. Risk currencies see little by way of pertinent scheduled events throughout the US and APAC sessions and thus will be on headline watch.

 

EM

Losses for the Lira amid sanction jitters following reports that Turkey has begun testing the radar on the Russian-made S-400 system it acquired earlier this year. Washington has previously moved its red lines on the imposition of CAATSA sanctions to the “activation” of the defence system from the “delivery”, but the testing of the radar equipment could risk provoking US lawmakers. USD/TRY extended on earlier upside and eclipsed 5.7500 to the upside (to a high of 5.7525 vs. a low of 5.7035) having surpassed its 100, 200 and 21 DMAs at 5.7099, 5.7164 and 5.7315 respectively.

25th November 2019

  • In the latest Barron’s publication, Pfizer’s (PFE) new strategy was suggested as worth looking into if investors could stomach some risk; electric vehicle makers (TSLA, F, GM) were mentioned cautiously, citing high-cost production; VMware (VMW) was mentioned cautiously, citing its core business at risk due to other cloud players; a selection of value stocks were mentioned positively on attractive valuations (BTI, FTI, BHP, HPE, AAPL, TSN, UNH, CI, CNC, ANTM, NLSN, DAL, UAL, RIO, LYB, DD).
  • Of note for banks, Deutsche Bank (DBK GY), Credit Suisse (CSGN SW), UBS (UBSG SW) and Barclays (BARC LN) have removed USD 280bln of assets from their main US holding companies within the previous four years in order to shield their businesses from regulatory scrutiny, the FT reports.

DOW

  • The Walt Disney Company (DIS) (Communication Services/Movies & Entertainment) – Frozen 2 exceed box office estimates on its opening weekend, raking in USD 350mln globally (USD 127mln domestically).

NASDAQ 100

  • Amazon.com Inc. (AMZN) (Consumer Discretionary/Internet & Direct Marketing Retail) has officially filed its lawsuit against the Pentagon for awarding Microsoft (MSFT) the USD 10bln cloud-computing contract, known as JEDI; Amazon has previously claimed that politics got in the way of the deal.
  • Netflix Inc. (NFLX) (Communication Services/Movies & Entertainment) has been downgraded to Underperform from Market Perform at Wells Fargo, where analyst Steven Cahall cut his price target to USD 265 from USD 308 after analysing Netflix’s cash estimates gave him conviction of much less than expected FCF up until 2025, citing subscriber growth as more expensive than consensus expects.
  • Nvidia Corporation (NVDA) (Information Technology/Semiconductors) has been upgraded to Overweight from Equal Weight at Morgan Stanley, where analyst Jason Moore raised his PT to USD 259 from USD 217 citing expectations of greater returns from its gaming segment next year following the investments it has made this year.
  • T Mobile US Inc (TMUS) (Communication Services/Wireless Telecommunication Services) said that some customer data in pre-paid accounts had been breached earlier in the month, affecting under 1.5% of its customer base, where the hack was reportedly quickly shut down, with the co. saying no financial data, social security numbers or passwords had been compromised.
  • Tesla Inc (TSLA) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobiles) CEO Musk has been tweeting its new Cybertruck pre-orders over the weekend, with the latest tweet putting the figure at 200k. Musk also tweeted the Cybertruck would be the last vehicle unveil for a while but there would be technology updates next year.

S&P 500

  • Altria Group Inc (MO) (Consumer Staples/Tobacco) – US President Trump is warming towards a minimum vaping age of 21 (currently 18) and is less keen on a prohibition on concerns of potentially creating a large black market, according to MarketWatch.
  • Charles Schwab Corporation (SCHW) (Financials/Investment Banking & Brokerage) confirmed it is to acquire TD Ameritrade (AMTD) (Financials/Capital Markets) in all stock acquisition at USD 26bln, where TD shareholders will receive 1.0837 Charles Schwab shares for each TD share; expected to close within 18 to 36 months conditional on regulatory and shareholder approval. The deal will be approximately 10-15% accretive to GAAP EPS and 15-20% accretive to operating cash EPS in the 3rd post-close year; expectations for USD 1.8bln-2.0bln run rate expense synergies.
  • General Electric (GE) (Industrials/Industrial Conglomerates) – Carolina Dybeck Happe is to become CFO, former CFO Miller has now departed the co; Dybeck Happe was previously the CFO of A.P Moller-Maersk (MAERSKB DC).
  • HP Inc. (HPQ) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals) has reiterated its rejection of Xerox’s (XRX) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals) offer, citing the offer as continuing to undervalue HP.
  • Jacobs Engineering Group (JEC) (Industrials/Construction & Engineering) Q4 19 (USD): Adj. EPS 1.48 (exp. 1.32), Revenue 3.4bln (exp. 3.22bln). Co announced it would be changing its name to Jacobs Solutions to represent its push into technology.
  • Occidental Petroleum (OXY) (Energy/Oil & Gas Exploration & Production) – Activist investor Carl Icahn is looking to nominate a slate of ten new directors before the November 29th deadline, according to sources.
  • Prudential Financial (PRU) (Financials/Life & Health Insurance) has been downgraded to Sell from Neutral at Citi, where analyst Suneet Kamath lowered his PT to USD 86 from USD 88 citing concerns of “if” the insurer can return back to above-peer growth and RoE - previously concerned on “when” – especially due to the low interest rate environment.
  • Tiffany & Co. (TIF) (Consumer Discretionary/Apparel, Accessories & Luxury Goods) will be acquired by LVMH (MC FP) for USD 135/share for an equity value of USD 16.2bln; expected to close in mid-2020 conditional on shareholder and regulatory approval.
  • Viacom Inc. (VIAB) (Communication Services/Movies & Entertainment) and CBS Corp. (CBS) (Communication Services/Broadcasting) – CBS has announced that upon completion of the merger, it will delist its Class A and Class B stock from the NYSE and relist on the Nasdaq Global Select Market under the name ViacomCBS Inc.

OTHER

  • Beigene Ltd (BGNE) (Health Care/Biotechnology) has presented “durable responses” from its Phase 2 clinical trial of tislelizumab, its anti-PD-1 therapy, in combination with chemotherapy for treatment of gastric/ gastroesophageal junction adenocarcinoma or esophageal squamous cell carcinoma.
  • Kirkland Lake Gold Ltd (KL) (Materials/Metals & Mining) is to acquire Detour Gold Corporation in an all-stock deal valued at CAD 4.9bln.
  • Medicines Company (MDCO) (Health Care/Biotechnology) has been acquired by Novartis (NOVN SW, NOV) for USD 85/share in cash, giving an equity value of USD 9.7bln; expected to close in Q1 2020 conditional on regulatory approval.
  • Uber Inc (UBER) (Industrials/Road & Rail) has had its London license stripped for the second time in two years over concerns for potential breaches; Uber called the decision “extraordinary and wrong” and said it would appeal.

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 25th November 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European bourses are firmer this morning as sentiment is supported by APAC newsflow
  • China is to increase penalties related to IP theft and will examine lowering the threshold for violators according to fresh government guidelines
  • Hong Kong Pro-democracy candidates achieved a landslide win following a record turnout in Hong Kong District Council elections
  • Datapraxis analysis on YouGov data projected a UK Conservative majority of 48 seats with a total of 349 seats
  • LVMH is to acquire Tiffany (TIF) for USD 135/shr, and London transport regulator will not grant Uber (UBER) a license for the city
  • Looking ahead, highlights include ECB’s Mersch & Fed's Powell

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets began the week on a positive note with sentiment underpinned by encouraging reports from the Greater China region in which Beijing released fresh guidelines to increase penalties on IP theft and after protesters eased tensions in Hong Kong for elections where pro-Democracy candidates achieved a landslide victory. ASX 200 (+0.3%) was led higher by the trade sensitive sectors such as tech and materials although financials lagged amid continued losses in Westpac due to the AUSTRAC breaches which prompted its Chairman Maxsted to put CEO Hartzer on notice that he could be fired if the scandal continues to destabilise the reputation of the bank, while Nikkei 225 (+0.8%) was underpinned by a weaker currency and with commodity-related sectors front running the advances. Hang Seng (+1.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.7%) conformed to the optimism after China’s steps to increase penalties on IP theft, which despite being vague in its promise, is still seen as an effort to appease the US side. In addition, Hong Kong was buoyed following the District Council elections where protests quietened to avert the risk of a cancellation and in which the pan-democratic camp won more than six-fold the number of seats than the pro-Beijing establishment, although gains in the mainland were to a lesser extent following a substantial CNY 180bln net liquidity drain by the PBoC. Finally, 10yr JGBs were relatively uneventful as focus centred on riskier assets, but with mild gains seen amid the BoJ’s presence in the market for JPY 890bln of JGBs with varying maturities.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net daily drain of CNY 180bln. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 7.0397 vs. Exp. 7.0421 (Prev. 7.0306)

China is to increase penalties related to IP theft and will examine lowering the threshold for violators according to fresh government guidelines, while reports added that the promise was vague and local governments will have the responsibility of implementing the changes. (Newswires)

Global Times tweeted that contrary to negative media reports, China and US are very close to a phase one deal and China remains committed to continuing talks for a phase two, or even a phase three deal with the US on equal footing, citing experts close to the government. (Twitter)

US National Security Adviser O’Brien said an initial trade agreement with China is still possible before year-end although he added that President Trump will not turn a blind eye to what is happening in Hong Kong or the South China Sea. In related news, a senior White House official said the Dec. 15th additional 15% tariffs are currently scheduled to go into effect on Chinese imports but added that things could change with potential good will if there is a phase one trade deal. (Newswires/Fox)

An ambitious “phase two” trade deal between the US and China is said to look less likely as the two countries struggle to strike a preliminary “phase one” agreement, according to reports citing US and Beijing officials, lawmakers and trade experts. (Newswires)

Hong Kong Pro-democracy candidates achieved a landslide win following a record turnout in Hong Kong District Council elections in which the results showed pan-democratic candidates won 390 seats of the 452 seats, while it was also reported that protests were quiet as protesters decided to ease tensions heading into the election to avoid the risk of a cancellation. (Newswires)

China is planning a record sales of USD sovereign bonds with a potential USD 6bln offering (3yr, 5yr, 10yr, 20yr,), according to SCMP sources. (SCMP)

US

Michael Bloomberg entered the race for the 2020 US Presidential Election as a Democratic Candidate. (Newswires)

China's Foreign Ministry reading the US designation Huawei and ZTE as national security threats, urges the US to stop its abuse of the concept of national security and Chinese Co's. (Newswires)

UK/EU

Datapraxis analysis on YouGov data projected a Conservative majority of 48 seats with a total of 349 seats, Labour 213, Lib Dems 14, SNP 49, Plaid Cymru 5, Green Party 1, Speaker 1. (Twitter) Elsewhere, according to Electoral Calculus, using research from five surveys carried out between November 14th-19th, the Conservatives are set to gain a 64-seat majority. (Telegraph)

Opinium UK election poll showed Conservatives at 47% (+3), Labour 28% (Unch.), Lib Dems 12% (-2) and Brexit Party 3% (-3), while Panelbase poll showed Conservatives at 42% (-1), Labour 32% (+2), Lib Dems 14% (-1) and Brexit Party 3% (-2), in surveys both conducted November 20th-22nd. (Guardian/Newswires) YouGov showed Conservatives at 42% (unch), Labour 30% (Unch.), Lib Dems 16% (+1) and Brexit Party 3% (-1), conducted November 21st-22nd. (Twitter)

UK PM Johnson launched the Conservative party manifesto in which he pledged to deliver Brexit by January 31 and spend GBP 100bln on infrastructure spending, while the policies included ruling out increases in income tax, National Insurance and VAT for 5 years. (Politico/BBC)

UK opposition Labour Party leader Corbyn said he would stay neutral in a 2nd Brexit referendum in an effort to rally support and carry out the will of the people. (Newswires)

SNP’s Leader Sturgeon says that they would be willing to support a Labour government if no party achieves a majority, but would not enter a formal coalition; scrapping of the Trident nuclear system would be a ‘red line’. (BBC)

German Ifo Business Climate New (Nov) 95.0 vs. Exp. 95.0 (Prev. 94.6, Rev. 94.7)

- Curr Conditions New (Nov) 97.9 vs. Exp. 98.0 (Prev. 97.8)

- Expectations New (Nov) 92.1 vs. Exp. 92.5 (Prev. 91.5, Rev. 91.6)

EQUITIES

Major European bourses (Euro Stoxx 50 +0.4%) are modestly firmer in quiet Monday morning trade (but off highs), as the region continues to benefit from weekend tailwinds in the form of further promises from the Chinese on IP and an easing of tensions in Hong Kong to allow for elections. Sectors are all in the green, with Consumer Discretionary (+1.2%) and Materials (+0.8%) in the lead, with the former boosted by outperformance in LVMH (+2.0%) after the luxury goods maker agreed to purchase Tiffany & Co. (+6.0% pre-market) for USD 135/shr, or USD 16.3bln. Further consolidation within the industry has prompted other luxury names, including Christian Dior (+2.0%), Richemont (+1.8%) and Kering (+0.9%) to move higher in sympathy. Elsewhere in M&A, Novartis (+0.4%) has agreed to acquire The Medicines Co. for a transaction value of USD 9.7bln on a fully diluted basis that includes outstanding stock options and convertible debt. Moreover, BHP (+1.1%) caught a bid amid price action within the base-metal complex, whilst reports stated that the Co. reportedly intends to increase its stake in SolGold further to 14.7% from 11%. In other notable stock specific news; IAG (+0.9%) are higher after British Airways agreed to a pilot pay deal to stop strike action with pilot union Balpa. Petrofac (-1.7%) is lower on the news that it had been identified as the energy Co. accused of having fake account for the purpose of disguising bribe payment to foreign government officials. Finally, of note for Just Eat (+0.2%); US competitor Uber (-5.6% pre-market) was not granted an operating license from London’s public transport regulator TfL.

LVMH (MC FP) – Co. has reached a deal to acquire Tiffany (TIF) for USD 135/shr in cash or USD 16.3bln, LVMH state that the acquisition is expected to close in the middle of 2020. (Newswires) Tiffany are approx. 5.95% higher in pre-market trade

Apple (AAPL) – Expects strong shipments for their 5G iPhones as according to sources. (DigiTimes)

Uber (UBER) – London’s transport regulator states they will not be granting the Co. a license. (Newswires) Co. are lower by circa 6% in pre-market trade.

Charles Schwab (SCHW) – Co. confirming they are to acquire TD Ameritrade (AMTD) in all stock acquisition at USD 26bln. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

North Korea leader Kim visited a military site and urged the army to be prepared for regular mobilization, while it was also reported that they will increase war-like drills. (Newswires)

Turkey is reportedly testing the S-400's radar system, according to reports. (Newswires)

FX

DXY, Yuan - The USD and Index kick-start a new week relatively directionless amid consolidation from Friday’s advances. The Dollar succumbed to slight pressure in APAC/early EU hours from trade developments over the weekend after vague reports that China will tighten laws around IP theft, which is seen as a step to appease the US amid stumbling blocks in Phase 1 talks. DXY remains above the 98.00 mark and around recent highs (98.30) and having sound support at its 50 DMA at 98.22. Meanwhile, the CNH feel some reprieve amid the China steps coupled with a firmer-than-forecast PBoC fixing. USD/CNH hovers around 7.0300 having gapped lower at the open last night, currency nearer to the bottom of the 7.0280-0420 daily band.

GBP, EUR - Sterling stands as the marked outperformer thus far and stages similar gains to last Monday as some weekend polls show a steady uptrend in the Conservative’s lead over the Labour party. Furthermore, analysis on YouGov data could be adding further fuel to the bullish fire as it projects the market-friendly Tory party with a parliamentary majority of 48. Cable has reclaimed 1.2850+ status having currently clocked in a range of 1.2842-85 as it eclipses its 21 DMA at 1.2878. Meanwhile, the Single Currency remains relatively uneventful and little swayed by the German Ifo Survey which printed a modest improvement in the three metrics but was caveated by cautious comments from the institute, who noted that it is too early to speak of a German economic turnaround. EUR/USD stay afloat just above 1.1000 with touted support around 1.0990-94 should the round figure be breached with ECB’s Mersch and Lane the EZ highlights post-Ifo, although some calendars also highlight hawk Holzmann on the docket.

AUD, NZD, JPY - All moving according with risk, albeit antipodeans have drifted off highs (amid a firming Buck) following an upbeat APAC performance due their China exposure and in light of the aforementioned China IP announcement, seemingly a concession in trade talks with the US. Further, Hong Kong saw a more peaceful weekend as local elections went underway – which concluded with a landslide win for the pro-democratic candidates and hopes of calm in the region in the aftermath. AUD/USD trades flat intraday having tested 0.6800 to the upside overnight (with AUD 800mln in options expiring between strikes 0.6780-90), although pressure on the Aussie could also stem from the AUD/NZD cross which backed off after failing to breach 1.06 to the upside. The cross also keeps the Kiwi buoyed and still above 0.6400 vs. the USD, having traded within a 20-pip range thus far. Elsewhere, USD/JPY hovers near session highs after printing a high of 108.90 in early trade after surpassing its 21 DMA at 108.76 with added upside in the pair as the Dollar gains traction.

EM - The Lira experiences renewed pressure amid reports that Turkey is testing the radars on the Russian made S-400 missile systems, thus potentially prompting backlash from US lawmakers who have threatened CAATSA sanctions should the system be activated. The news of the tests largely overshadows reports of Turkey ceasing military operations in Northern Syria as per its agreement with Russia. USD/TRY topped its 100 and 21 DMAs (5.7100 and 5.7317 respectively) ahead of potential resistance at its 50 DMA (5.7500) with eyes now on any action from US Congress.

Notable FX option expiries for today's NY cut:

- AUD/USD: 0.6780-90 (800M)

- USD/JPY: 108.50-60 (500M)

 

SNB Economist Lenz says that it is too early to tell when the deposit rate will move back above, zero, adding that rates could be cut further, albeit, they cannot fall on an indefinite basis. (Newswires)

Taiwan Government are to purchase more US goods to avoid being named a currency manipulator, which includes military equipment, oil, gas and agri products., sources. (Newswires)

FIXED INCOME

A slightly softer start to the week for bonds, as sentiment remains supported by the weekend’s developments out of Asia with the Hong Kong elections recording record turnout and an overwhelming win for the pre-Democracy parties. Additionally, China are to increase IP theft penalties, a positive sign given this has been one of the sticking points throughout negotiations; although, reports noted this commitment is vague. Turning to price action Bunds are rangebound within relatively tight parameters around the 171.0 mark. Today’s highlight thus far has been the German Ifo survey which printed broadly in-line, spurring little Bund reaction, with ING noting this adds to the evidence of a bottoming out for the European powerhouse but caveating that it does not equate to a recovery. From a technical perspective, 171.35 and 170.26 may present resistance and support respectively in the event of a break from ranges. Elsewhere, from a UK perspective Gilts are flat this morning and in close proximity to opening levels, with some initially downside in the bond on weekend polling showing the Conservative party maintains a significant lead (as much as 19pp above Labour) and are projected by some to win a comfortable circa 50 seat majority. Looking ahead and to the States where the schedule is sparse at the starts of a holiday week with no data points, but Fed’s Powell is to speak at 00:00GMT/19:00ET for the Greater Providence Chamber of Commerce. Note, the US curve is currently bear steepening.

COMMODITIES                                      

Crude markets are in consolidation, with WTI and Brent front months contracts rangebound just below the USD 58.00/bbl and USD 63.80/bbl levels respectively, as the complex largely fails to garner any impetus from the more favourable macro backdrop. Crude specific news flow has been on the light side; there have been some scheduling updates – JMMC and OPEC meetings will reportedly both take place on the 5th of December, with OPEC+ meeting a day later. In terms of the metals; more favourable risk appetite has seen copper advance; the red metal managed to eke out two-week highs and trades just above its 21 DMA at USD 2.6567/lb. Meanwhile, lack of demand for havens sees gold under pressure; the precious metal is now rangebound around the USD 1458/oz level. Finally, Dalian iron ore futures climbed over 3.0% with upside attributed to trade optimism amid the latest headlines.

Goldman Sachs sees 2019 WTI prices at USD 56.90/bbl and 2020 at USD 55.50/bbl, while it sees 2020 non-OPEC supply to increase 2.1mln bpd and demand growth of 1.2mln bpd. Goldman Sachs said its 2020 top trade recommendation is long oil-heavy enhanced S&P GSCI Index and that it sees oil returns of 10% next year despite maintaining USD 60/bbl oil forecast, while it affirmed its bullish gold target of USD 1600/oz. (Newswires)

OPEC and JMMC meetings will both take place on the 5th December, according to Energyintel's Bakr. (Twitter)

subject: Charles Schwab (SCHW) – Co. confirming it is to acquire TD Ameritrade (AMTD) in all stock acquisition at USD 26bln
content:
• Deal will be circa. 10-15% accretive to GAAP EPS and 15-20% accretive to operating cash EPS in the 3rd post-close year
  • TD shareholders will receive 1.0837 Charles Schwab shares for each TD share
  • Current estimates are for circa. USD 1.8bln to 2.0bln run rate expense synergies for the deal

Additional European equity stories post the release of the Daily European equity opening news
content:
LVMH (MC FP) – Co. has reached a deal to acquire Tiffany (TIF) for USD 135/shr in cash or USD 16.3bln, LVMH state that the acquisition is expected to close in the middle of 2020. (Newswires)

Altice (ATC NA) – Co. have acquired Covage. (Newswires)

Osram Licht (OSR GY) – Temasek, the biggest investor in AMS (AMS AV) with a 5.4% stake, are supporting the takeover of Osram Lich according to Euro am Sonntag. (Newswires)

PSA (UG FP)/ Fiat Chrysler (FCA IM) – PSA remains focused on talks with Fiat Chrsyler and still aims to sign an MoU in December, according to sources. (Newswires)

Icade (ICAD FP) – Co. increase net current cash flow guidance for 2019, and confirm their dividend policy at circa +4.5%. (Newswires)

Mediaset (MS IM)/ Vivendi (VIV FP) – Vivendi is said to be in talks to sell back to Mediaset two-thirds of its 29% stake in the Co. for EUR 2.77 plus a compensation. (Newswires)

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

25th November 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700GMT/0100CST recapping all of the   overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0100CST all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0115CST.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0150CST recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0115CST ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets began the week on a positive note with sentiment underpinned by encouraging reports from the Greater China region in which Beijing released fresh guidelines to increase penalties on IP theft and after protesters eased tensions in Hong Kong for elections where pro-Democracy candidates achieved a landslide victory. ASX 200 (+0.3%) was led higher by the trade sensitive sectors such as tech and materials although financials lagged amid continued losses in Westpac due to the AUSTRAC breaches which prompted its Chairman Maxsted to put CEO Hartzer on notice that he could be fired if the scandal continues to destabilise the reputation of the bank, while Nikkei 225 (+0.7%) was underpinned by a weaker currency and with commodity-related sectors front running the advances. Hang Seng (+1.8%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.6%) conformed to the optimism after China’s steps to increase penalties on IP theft, which despite being vague in its promise, is still seen as an effort to appease the US side. In addition, Hong Kong was buoyed following the District Council elections where protests quietened to avert the risk of a cancellation and in which the pan-democratic camp won more than six-folds the number of seats than the pro-Beijing establishment, although gains in the mainland were to a lesser extent following a substantial CNY 180bln net liquidity drain by the PBoC.

FTSE 100

BHP (BHP LN) – Co. reportedly intend to increase their stake in SolGold according to sources. Note, Co. currently have a 11% stake in SolGold. (Newswires)

Unilever (ULVR LN) – Co. is said to be mulling the sale of its traditional tea business including the PG Tips and Lipton brands due to cooling demand for British tea, according to sources. (Telegraph)

National Grid (NG/ LN)/SSE (SSE LN) – Co’s have confirmed they have created new Co’s for sections of their business which they believe are vulnerable to nationalisation via a Labour government; new Co’s have been registered in Switzerland, Luxembourg and Hong Kong. Note, this would not prevent the Co’s from being taken over but may safeguard investors. (Times/BBC)

IAG (IAG LN) – British Airways has agreed to a pilot pay deal to stop strike action with pilot union Balpa. Have reportedly added, amongst other measures, an inflation cause to the prev. offer of a 11.5% pay rise over a 3-year period. (FT)

Rio Tinto (RIO LN) – Co’s CEO said he is prepared to engage with the Mongolia Government over the potential improvements relating to agreements regarding the Oyu Tolgoi mine expansion. (Newswires)

Housing/Rental Names – Labour Government have vowed to instigate rent controls if they win the election, which would stop private rents from increasing by more than inflation. (BBC)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

Petrofac (PFC LN) – Co. have been identified as the energy Co. accused of having fake account for the purpose of disguising bribe payment to foreign government officials. Co. state that no charges have been implemented since the Serious Fraud Office began the investigation into bribery and money laundering 3-years ago. (Guardian)

BROKER MOVES

DIRECT LINE (DLG LN) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM HOLD AT DEUTSCHE BANK

HAYS (HAS LN) DOWNGRADED TO UNDERPERFORM FROM NEUTRAL AT CREDIT SUISSE

DAX

Volkswagen (VOW3 GY) – Almost half a million customers who purchased Co. vehicles with software to cheat emissions tests may miss out on compensation due to a backlog of paperwork. (FT)

BASF (BAS GY) – Co. has begun work on a USD 10bln petrochemical facility in China. (FT)

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

Audi (NSU GY) – Co. are reportedly to reach a agreement this week regarding German job cuts., according to press. (Newswires) Also of note for Volkswagen (VOW3 GY).

BROKER MOVES

CAC

LVMH (MC FP) – Co. has reportedly reached a deal to acquire Tiffany (TIF) for USD 135/shr in cash or USD 16.3bln, according to sources which added than an agreement could be announced as soon as today. (CNBC)

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

Edenred (EDEN FP) – Co. are restoring operations following on from a malware attack, no evidence suggesting that personal data was accessed. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

PAN EUROPE

Deutsche Bank (DBK GY)/Credit Suisse (CSGN SW)/UBS (UBSG SW)/Barclays (BARC LN) – Co’s have removed USD 280bln of assets from their main US holding Co’s within the previous 4-years; to shield their businesses from regulators. (FT)

BROKER MOVES

EUROPEAN STAINLESS STEEL INITIATED WITH A NEGATIVE VIEW AT CREDIT SUISSE

SAIPEM (SPM IM) DOWNGRADED TO EQUAL WEIGHT FROM OVERWEIGHT AT BARCLAYS

SMI

Novartis (NOVN SW) – Co. has agreed to acquire The Medicines Co. (MDCO) for a transaction value of USD 9.7bln on a fully diluted basis that includes outstanding stock options and convertible debt. (FT)

Roche (ROG SW) – FDA has granted priority review to Co’s Risdiplan for spinal muscular athropy. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

SCANDINAVIA

Orsted (ORSTED DC) – Co. are reportedly in talks to construct a offshore wind-farm in Poland., according to press. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

OUTOKUMU (OUT1V FH) INITIATED WITH UNDERPERFORM AT CREDIT SUISSE

US

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 25th November 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian equity markets began the week on a positive note with sentiment underpinned by encouraging reports from China
  • China is to increase penalties related to IP theft and will examine lowering the threshold for violators according to fresh government guidelines
  • Hong Kong Pro-democracy candidates achieved a landslide win following a record turnout in Hong Kong District Council elections
  • US President Trump said the China trade deal is coming along very well, while he also commented that an announcement will come "very soon" regarding the Hong Kong bill
  • Datapraxis analysis on YouGov data projected a Conservative majority of 48 seats with a total of 349 seats
  • Looking ahead, German Ifo, ECB’s Mersch

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets began the week on a positive note with sentiment underpinned by encouraging reports from the Greater China region in which Beijing released fresh guidelines to increase penalties on IP theft and after protesters eased tensions in Hong Kong for elections where pro-Democracy candidates achieved a landslide victory. ASX 200 (+0.3%) was led higher by the trade sensitive sectors such as tech and materials although financials lagged amid continued losses in Westpac due to the AUSTRAC breaches which prompted its Chairman Maxsted to put CEO Hartzer on notice that he could be fired if the scandal continues to destabilise the reputation of the bank, while Nikkei 225 (+0.7%) was underpinned by a weaker currency and with commodity-related sectors front running the advances. Hang Seng (+1.8%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.6%) conformed to the optimism after China’s steps to increase penalties on IP theft, which despite being vague in its promise, is still seen as an effort to appease the US side. In addition, Hong Kong was buoyed following the District Council elections where protests quietened to avert the risk of a cancellation and in which the pan-democratic camp won more than six-fold the number of seats than the pro-Beijing establishment, although gains in the mainland were to a lesser extent following a substantial CNY 180bln net liquidity drain by the PBoC. Finally, 10yr JGBs were relatively uneventful as focus centred on riskier assets, but with mild gains seen amid the BoJ’s presence in the market for JPY 890bln of JGBs with varying maturities.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net daily drain of CNY 180bln. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 7.0397 vs. Exp. 7.0421 (Prev. 7.0306)

China is to increase penalties related to IP theft and will examine lowering the threshold for violators according to fresh government guidelines, while reports added that the promise was vague and local governments will have the responsibility of implementing the changes. (Newswires)

Global Times tweeted that contrary to negative media reports, China and US are very close to a phase one deal and China remains committed to continuing talks for a phase two, or even a phase three deal with the US on equal footing, citing experts close to the government. (Twitter)

US President Trump said the China trade deal is coming along very well, while he also commented that an announcement will come "very soon" regarding the Hong Kong bill. (Newswires)

US National Security Adviser O’Brien said an initial trade agreement with China is still possible before year-end although he added that President Trump will not turn a blind eye to what is happening in Hong Kong or the South China Sea. In related news, a senior White House official said the Dec. 15th additional 15% tariffs are currently scheduled to go into effect on Chinese imports but added that things could change with potential good will if there is a phase one trade deal. (Newswires/Fox)

An ambitious “phase two” trade deal between the US and China is said to look less likely as the two countries struggle to strike a preliminary “phase one” agreement, according to reports citing US and Beijing officials, lawmakers and trade experts. (Newswires)

Hong Kong Pro-democracy candidates achieved a landslide win following a record turnout in Hong Kong District Council elections in which the results showed pan-democratic candidates won 390 seats of the 452 seats, while it was also reported that protests were quiet as protesters decided to ease tensions heading into the election to avoid the risk of a cancellation. (Newswires)

UK/EU

Datapraxis analysis on YouGov data projected a Conservative majority of 48 seats with a total of 349 seats, Labour 213, Lib Dems 14, SNP 49, Plaid Cymru 5, Green Party 1, Speaker 1. (Twitter) Elsewhere, according to Electoral Calculus, using research from five surveys carried out between November 14th-19th, the Conservatives are set to gain a 64-seat majority. (Telegraph)

 

Opinium UK election poll showed Conservatives at 47% (+3), Labour 28% (Unch.), Lib Dems 12% (-2) and Brexit Party 3% (-3), while Panelbase poll showed Conservatives at 42% (-1), Labour 32% (+2), Lib Dems 14% (-1) and Brexit Party 3% (-2), in surveys both conducted November 20th-22nd. (Guardian/Newswires) YouGov showed Conservatives at 42% (unch), Labour 30% (Unch.), Lib Dems 16% (+1) and Brexit Party 3% (-1), conducted November 21st-22nd. (Twitter)

 

UK PM Johnson launched the Conservative party manifesto in which he pledged to deliver Brexit by January 31 and spend GBP 100bln on infrastructure spending, while the policies included ruling out increases in income tax, National Insurance and VAT for 5 years. (Politico/BBC)

 

UK opposition Labour Party leader Corbyn said he would stay neutral in a 2nd Brexit referendum in an effort to rally support and carry out the will of the people. (Newswires)

 

SNP’s Leader Sturgeon says that they would be willing to support a Labour government if no party achieves a majority, but would not enter a formal coalition; scrapping of the Trident nuclear system would be a ‘red line’. (BBC)

 

Fitch affirmed Austria at 'AA+'; Outlook Positive, affirmed Portugal at 'BBB', Outlook Positive and affirmed Iceland at A; Outlook Stable. (Newswires)

 

FX

DXY was steady and held near last week’s highs, nonetheless, EUR/USD found some respite as the 1.1015 level provided a floor for the currency and GBP/USD partially nursed losses after the latest Opinium poll showed the Conservatives widened their lead to 19 points against the opposition Labour Party, with the Datapraxis analysis on YouGov surveys also projecting the Conservatives are set for a majority win of 48 seats. Elsewhere, USD/JPY was lifted by the risk appetite and broke through several shorter-term DMAs as it closes in on the 200DMA at 108.94, while antipodeans mildly benefitted from the risk appetite and somewhat improved trade optimism due to their high-beta properties and China exposure.

SNB Economist Lenz says that it is too early to tell when the deposit rate will move back above, zero, adding that rates could be cut further, albeit, they cannot fall on an indefinite basis. (Newswires)

S&P affirmed South Africa at BB; Outlook revised to Negative from Stable. (Newswires) COMMODITIES

Commodities were uneventful overnight in which WTI crude futures only marginally benefitted from the positive risk tone as prices were contained by near-term resistance around the USD 58.00/bbl, with a mild reduction of oil rigs in the latest Baker Hughes rig count and some favourable oil-based forecasts for next year by Goldman Sachs doing little to spur prices. Elsewhere, gold was lacklustre around the USD 1460/oz level amid a lack of safe-haven demand and as the greenback held on to recent gains, while copper conformed to the quiet tone in commodities and only eked minimal gains despite the improved US-China trade headlines.

Baker Hughes Rig Count (22 Nov): Oil rigs -3 at 671, natgas rigs unchanged at 129, total rigs -3 at 803. (Newswires) Goldman Sachs sees 2019 WTI prices at USD 56.90/bbl and 2020 at USD 55.50/bbl, while it sees 2020 non-OPEC supply to increase 2.1mln bpd and demand growth of 1.2mln bpd. Goldman Sachs said its 2020 top trade recommendation is long oil-heavy enhanced S&P GSCI Index and that it sees oil returns of 10% next year despite maintaining USD 60/bbl oil forecast, while it affirmed its bullish gold target of USD 1600/oz. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

North Korea leader Kim visited a military site and urged the army to be prepared for regular mobilization, while it was also reported that they will increase war-like drills. (Newswires)

US

 

The T-Plex was lower for the second consecutive week on Friday with losses inspired by upside in the equity complex, with hints from US President Trump that a trade deal with China is "potentially very close". The data slate was also supportive, with a better than expected US Markit PMI, while University of Michigan consumer sentiment data was revised higher, boding well CB gauge of consumer confidence, released next week. Volumes were light, and at settlement, the curve was mixed, with the 2s through 7s higher yields, 10s roughly unchanged, while 30s yields were slightly lower; major curve spreads, however, narrowed by around 1-2bps. US T-note futures (Z9) settled 1 tick lower at 129-14+.

Michael Bloomberg entered the race for the 2020 US Presidential Election as a Democratic Candidate. (Newswires)

Asia equity markets begin the week on a positive note with sentiment underpinned by encouraging reports from the Greater China region in which Beijing released fresh guidelines to increase penalties on IP theft and after protesters eased tensions in Hong Kong for elections where pro-Democracy candidates are set for a landslide victory. ASX 200 (+0.3%) is led higher by the trade sensitive sectors such as tech and materials although financials lag amid continued losses in Westpac due to the AUSTRAC breaches which prompted its Chairman Maxsted to put CEO Hartzer on notice that he could be fired if the scandal continues to destabilise the reputation of the bank, while Nikkei 225 (+1.2%) is underpinned by a weaker currency and with commodity related sectors front running the advances. Hang Seng (+1.8%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.5%) conform to the upbeat tone after China’s steps to increase penalties on IP theft which despite being vague in its promise, is still seen as an effort to appease the US side. In addition, Hong Kong is buoyed following the District Council elections where protests quietened to avert the risk of a cancellation and in which the pan-democratic camp were set to win more than six-folds the number of seats than the pro-Beijing establishment, although gains in the mainland were to a lesser extent following a substantial CNY 180bln net liquidity drain by the PBoC.

In FX markets, the DXY is steady and holds near last week’s highs where it had been spurred by stronger than expected US PMI data and weakness across its European counterparts due to their less-encouraging PMI releases. Nonetheless, EUR/USD has found some respite with 1.1015 level providing a floor for the currency and GBP/USD partially nurses losses after the latest Opinium poll showed Conservatives widened their lead to 47% (+3) vs. Labour at 28% (Unch.), with the Datapraxis analysis on YouGov surveys also projecting the Conservatives are set for a majority win of 349 seats. Elsewhere, USD/JPY is lifted by the risk appetite and has broken through several shorter-term DMAs as it homes in on the 200DMA at 108.94, while antipodeans mildly benefit from the risk appetite due to their high-beta properties and the somewhat improved trade optimism.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are relatively uneventful with demand subdued by the heightened risk appetite but with downside pressure also alleviated by the BoJ’s presence in the market for JPY 890bln of JGBs with varying maturities.

subject: Report notes an ambitious “phase two” trade deal between the US and China is looking less likely as the two countries struggle to strike a preliminary “phase one” agreement, according to US and Beijing officials, as well as lawmakers and trade experts
analysis_details: As a reminder, this is inline with reports from early last week that suggested that there was now wide scepticism on both sides on whether a more comprehensive phase 2 agreement (which would include provisions on structural reforms and enforcement) can ever be reached.

subject: Asia equity markets begin higher with sentiment lifted by encouraging news from the Greater China region including reports China released fresh guidelines to increase penalties on IP theft and after protesters eased tensions in Hong Kong for elections
